title: Editando arquivos com ex / vim
description: Como montar scripts de edição de arquivos.

props.code:
ex foo.txt <<-EOF
  g/^\s*$/d
  %s/^/[/
  %s/\(.*\)\(\s\+\)\(.*\)/\3\2\1
  %s/$/]/
  %s/design/test/
  wq " Update changes and quit.
EOF

children.value:
ex foo.txt <<-EOF
  g/^\s*$/d
  %s/^/[/
  %s/\(.*\)\(\s\+\)\(.*\)/\3\2\1
  %s/$/]/
  %s/design/test/
  wq " Update changes and quit.
EOF
How to run a series of vim commands from command prompt

props.code:
ex foo.txt <<-EOF
  g/^\s*$/d
  %s/^/[/
  %s/\(.*\)\(\s\+\)\(.*\)/\3\2\1
  %s/$/]/
  %s/design/test/
  wq " Update changes and quit.
EOF

:%y+          " copia o buffer todo para uso em qualquer aplicação externa
gg"+yG
gg"*yG

props.code:
" Vim compiler file
" Compiler:     MQL4
" Maintainer: Me
" Last Change:  2017 Apr 20

if exists("current_compiler")
  finish
endif
let current_compiler = "mql4"

CompilerSet makeprg=mkmql4\ % 
let &errorformat='%f(%l\,%c) : %m'

let &cpo = s:cpo_save
unlet s:cpo_save

" vim: sw=2 ts=2 et

title: Vim Spell Checking
description:
There are times when we edit prose in Vim,
such as in a project README or Git commit message.
In those cases,
we can use Vim's spell-checking to help us avoid embarrassing mistakes.

children.value:
There are times when we edit prose in Vim,
such as in a project

or Git commit message.
In those cases,
we can use Vim's spell-checking to help us avoid embarrassing mistakes.
We can switch on spell checking with this command:
We can also specify the language:
Here's a screenshot of what I see as I edit this blog post:
The highlighted words are considered misspellings.

It would be tedious to manually turn on spell-checking each time we need it.
Luckily, we can guess by convention that we'll want to spell-check certain files.

We automatically turn on spell-checking for Markdown files based on their file
extension with this line in our
Another way to do it for certain filetypes is like this:
We get word completion for free
By turning on spell-checking in our

, we'll be turning on word
completion as well. The following command will let us press
in insert-mode to complete the word we're typing!
We can add words like "RSpec" or "thoughtbot" to the

(a list of correctly-spelled words)
by cursoring over those words in a file and typing:

title: Run Tests in Vim
description:
Test driven development thrives on a tight feedback loop
but switching from the editor to the shell
to manually run specs is inefficient.

children.value:
Test driven development thrives on a tight feedback loop
but switching from the editor to the shell
to manually run specs is inefficient.

run specs whenever a file gets saved.
Although an improvement over a manual workflow,
those approaches often run the suite when not needed
and run too many or too few specs.

,
a lightweight Vim plugin that runs specs directly from within Vim
with the press of a key.

,
which can be bound to a key mapping of your choice.
In
Cursor over any line within an RSpec spec like this:

props.code:
describe RecipientInterceptor do
  it 'overrides to/cc/bcc fields' do
    Mail.register_interceptor RecipientInterceptor.new(recipient_string)

    response = deliver_mail

    expect(response.to).to eq [recipient_string]
    expect(response.cc).to eq []
    expect(response.bcc).to eq []
  end
end

children.value:
describe RecipientInterceptor do
  it 'overrides to/cc/bcc fields' do
    Mail.register_interceptor RecipientInterceptor.new(recipient_string)

    response = deliver_mail

    expect(response.to).to eq [recipient_string]
    expect(response.cc).to eq []
    expect(response.bcc).to eq []
  end
end

props.code:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb:4
.

Finished in 0.03059 seconds
1 example, 0 failures

children.value:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb:4
.

Finished in 0.03059 seconds
1 example, 0 failures

The screen is overtaken by a shell that runs only the focused spec.
Developers using tmux with vim-rspec and tslime
sometimes send the output to a nearby shell
so the code and spec output display on the screen at the same time.

Feeling good that this new spec passes,
run the whole file's specs with
to make sure the class's entire functionality is still intact:

props.code:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb
......

Finished in 0.17752 seconds
6 examples, 0 failures

children.value:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb
......

Finished in 0.17752 seconds
6 examples, 0 failures

Red, green, refactor.
From within the application's or library's code:

props.code:
def delivering_email(message)
  add_custom_headers message
  add_subject_prefix message
  message.to = @recipients
  message.cc = []
  message.bcc = []
end

children.value:
def delivering_email(message)
  add_custom_headers message
  add_subject_prefix message
  message.to = @recipients
  message.cc = []
  message.bcc = []
end
without having to switch back to the spec:

props.code:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb
......

Finished in 0.17752 seconds
6 examples, 0 failures

children.value:
rspec spec/recipient_interceptor_spec.rb
......

Finished in 0.17752 seconds
6 examples, 0 failures

These tight feedback loops make Test-Driven Development easier
by eliminating the switching cost between editor to the shell
when running specs.

title: Fast Search in Vim
description: Projects can be searched for specific text within Vim:

children.value: Projects can be searched for specific text within Vim:
Override to use The Silver Searcher

is a built-in command of Vim.
By default, it will use the system's

command.
We can overwrite it to use

props.code:
" The Silver Searcher
if executable('ag')
  " Use ag over grep
  set grepprg=ag\ --nogroup\ --nocolor

  " Use ag in CtrlP for listing files. Lightning fast and respects .gitignore
  let g:ctrlp_user_command = 'ag %s -l --nocolor -g ""'

  " ag is fast enough that CtrlP doesn't need to cache
  let g:ctrlp_use_caching = 0
endif

children.value:
" The Silver Searcher
if executable('ag')
  " Use ag over grep
  set grepprg=ag\ --nogroup\ --nocolor

  " Use ag in CtrlP for listing files. Lightning fast and respects .gitignore
  let g:ctrlp_user_command = 'ag %s -l --nocolor -g ""'

  " ag is fast enough that CtrlP doesn't need to cache
  let g:ctrlp_use_caching = 0
endif
Search for the word under the cursor

This searches for the text under the cursor
and shows the results in a "quickfix" window:

props.code:
" bind K to grep word under cursor
nnoremap K :grep! "\b<C-R><C-W>\b"<CR>:cw<CR>

children.value:
" bind K to grep word under cursor
nnoremap K :grep! "\b<C-R><C-W>\b"<CR>:cw<CR>
is typed with the cursor over
Cursor over each search result, hit
, and the file will be opened.

to search for the provided text
and open a "quickfix" window:

props.code:
" bind \ (backward slash) to grep shortcut
command -nargs=+ -complete=file -bar Ag silent! grep! <args>|cwindow|redraw!

children.value:
" bind \ (backward slash) to grep shortcut
command -nargs=+ -complete=file -bar Ag silent! grep! <args>|cwindow|redraw!

links.text: Override to use The Silver Searcher
Search for the word under the cursor

props.code:
cd ~/git
git clone https://github.com/vim/vim.git
cd vim

./configure --with-compiledby="Geraldo Ribeiro <geraldolsribeiro@gmail.com>" \
--with-features=huge \
--enable-gui=auto \
--with-x \
--enable-rubyinterp \

--enable-pythoninterp --with-python-config-dir=/usr/lib/python2.7/config \
--enable-fontset \
--enable-cscope \
--enable-gtk2-check \
--enable-gnome-check

make

title: Vim args, argdo
description:
O editor vim nos ajuda muito quando precisamos editar uma grande quantidade de
arquivos para realizar uma refatoração ou realizar modificações em lote.

children.value:
O editor vim nos ajuda muito quando precisamos editar uma grande quantidade de
arquivos para realizar uma refatoração ou realizar modificações em lote.
Carregar todos os arquivos que são rastreados pelo controle de versão que contenham a palavra
faz listar somente os arquivos sem o texto que faz match.
